questions.text: A person presented to OPD with complaints of rotatory vertigo and nausea in the morning on change in position of the head. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BPPV BBPV is the best answer. Vertigo with change in head position is characteristic of BPPV.

Highyeild:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) BPPV is the most common cause of vertigo in clinical practice. The patient complains of episodic vertigo lasting for seconds in certain head positions. Hearing is absolutely normal. Pathogenesis BPPV occurs because of free floating debris in the endolymph of posterior semicircular canal. The free floating debris moves in certain head positions, stimulating the cupula leading to vertigo. This vertigo disappears when the debris settles down in 10–20 seconds. Most common cause is head trauma. Other causes are middle ear infection, viral labyrinthitis, and prolonged bed rest. Diagnosis It is diagnosed by doing Hallpike Test which is an appositional test. In this test, the nystagmus is watched for while changing the position of the head of the patient while sitting and lying down. Management Epley’s maneuver or canalith repositioning maneuver: This Involves repositioning the debris from posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle by placing the patient’s head in a sequence of five positions. Meniere’s Disease It is also known as endolymphatic hydrops. It is frequently a unilateral condition and is seen more commonly in young females (20–40 years). It is largely idiopathic. Clinical Features Vertigo: It is the first symptom of Meniere’s disease and lasts for at least 20 minutes till a maximum of up to 24 hours. This sudden onset of vertigo of Meniere’s disease is associated with vagal symptoms, i.e., nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and bradycardia. SN hearing loss and tinnitus can be seen. Investigations Rinne test: Positive Weber test: Toward the normal ear ABC: Shortened Schwabach: Shortened Recruitment: Positive SISIS: 70–100% (because of recruitment) Management Salt and water restrictions Labyrinthine sedatives Vasodilators Meniett device Vestibular neuronitis This condition is characterized by acute onset vertigo, nystagmus and tinnitus with nausea and vomiting lasting for days to weeks. This is most likely because of the viral infection involving the vestibular nerve. The cochlear part is not involved, so the hearing remains normal. The caloric test shows diminished response. It is managed by labyrinthine sedatives.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male complains of nasal obstruction, nasal blockage, a mass is seen in the nasopharynx with minimal extension into sphenoid sinus. What is the stage of nasopharyngeal fibroma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IB Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It is typically seen in young adolescent males, i.e. occurs near puberty, hence called juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Clinical features: Recurrent episodes of profuse epistasis Unilateral nasal obstruction Nasal bones leading to broadening of nasal bridge Red fleshy mass can be seen in the nasal cavity Investigations CECT: It is the golden test Antral sign/Holman Miller sign seen Staging of angiofibroma Radkowski Classifications I A Limited to nose and/or nasopharyngeal vault B Extension into 1 paranasal sinus II A Minimal extension through sphenopalatine foramen into sphenopalatine/pterygomaxillary fossa B Fills sphenopalatine fossa bowing the posterior wall of the maxillary antrum anteriorly or extending into the orbit via the inferior orbital fissure C Extends beyond sphenopalatine fossa into infratemporal fossa III A Erosion of skull base—minimal intracranial extension B Erosion of skull base—extensive intracranial extension with or without cavernous sinus invasion Treatment : Surgical excision Radiotherapy is indicated in stage III, when tumor has intracranial extension.
